class_notes:
(Freshmen Only)
How has the meaning of citizenship has changed in US history?  How do ideals of citizenship compare with historical realities?  How have social groups pressed for expansive and inclusive citizenship?  What are the effects of current extreme economic inequality upon citizenship and representative democracy? Topics also include voting rights, immigration, nationalism, consumerism, social justice, global citizenship, and recent national elections. 
This discussion-based seminar draws upon a variety of source materials including the writings of historians, primary documents, critical essays, video documentaries, music and visual art of social protest, and contemporary internet resources.
course_description: Introduces first-year students to the discipline of history, particularly historical sources and methods; aims to improve critical reading, analytical, and writing skills in small group discussion.
sections: Class Nbr: 1146, Section #: 5, Type: SEM, Campus: ATL, Meets: TTh 2:30-3:45p, Instructor: A. Tullos, Status: Open
